Recall: from last time, we showed that...

If we assume that for all x,yRdx,yRd, f(x)f(y)Lxyf(x)f(y)Lxy, then

f(wt+1)f(wt)(112L)f(wt)2.f(wt+1)f(wt)(112L)f(wt)2.

If we choose our step size to be small enough that 1L1L, then this simplifies to

f(wt+1)f(wt)2f(wt)2.f(wt+1)f(wt)2f(wt)2.

That is, the objective is guaranteed to decrease at each iteration! This matches our intuition for why gradient descent should work.

An aside...why do we need sufficiently small step size?

With too large a step size, we can overshoot the optimum!

Consider the following case of f(w)=12w2f(w)=12w2. Here f(w)=f(w)=wf(w)=f(w)=w (and f(w)=1f(w)=1), so it's LL-smooth with L=1L=1. Suppose we're at wt=2wt=2 as shown here:

Here our GD update will be wt+1=wtf(wt)=22wt+1=wtf(wt)=22. If we step with =1=1, we go directly to the optimum at w=0w=0. But! If we step with a larger , we overshoot, and for >2>2, our loss f(w)f(w) actually increases. This illustrates why having sufficiently small steps is necessary for our proof.

Why is our L-smoothness assumption necessary?

We can also use a simple example to illustrate why assuming some sort of smoothness is necessary to show this result. Consider the (dumb) example of f(w)=|w|f(w)=|w|. It is differentiable everywhere except at w=0w=0.

Stochastic Gradient Descent

Basic idea: in gradient descent, just replace the full gradient (which is a sum) with a single gradient example. Initialize the parameters at some value w0Rdw0Rd, and decrease the value of the empirical risk iteratively by sampling a random example x(t)x(t) uniformly from the training set and then updating

wt+1=wttf(wt;x(t))wt+1=wttf(wt;x(t))

where as usual wtwt is the value of the parameter vector at time tt, tt is the learning rate or step size, and fifi denotes the gradient of the loss function of the iith training example. Compared with gradient descent and Newton's method, SGD is simple to implement and runs each iteration faster.

A potential objection!

This is not necessarily going to be decreasing the loss at every step!

  • Because we're just moving in a direction that will decrease the loss for one particular example: this won't necessarily decrease the total loss!

  • So we can't demonstrate convergence by using a proof like the one we used for gradient descent, where we showed that the loss decreases at every iteration of the algorithm.

  • The fact that SGD doesn't always improve the loss at each iteration motivates the question: does SGD even work? And if so, why does SGD work?

Question: Why might it be fine to get an approximate solution to an optimization problem for training?

Question: Why might it be fine to get an approximate solution to an optimization problem for training?

Because we don't always have to minimize the training loss exactly, as long as the performance on the test set is good enough. In machine learning, generalization matters more than optimization, sadly (for an optimizer).

Understanding why SGD converges

Assumption: ff is LL-smooth, i.e. for any xx and yy f(x)f(y)Lxy.f(x)f(y)Lxy.

Assumption: loss ff is non-negative. (This is without loss of generality if ff is bounded from below, since we can always add a constant to ff in that case to make it non-negative.)

New Assumption for SGD: the variance of the gradients is bounded. For some constant >0>0, if xx is drawn uniformly at random from the training set, for any ww Ex[f(w;x)f(w)2]2,Ex[f(w;x)f(w)2]2, or equivalently, 1nxDf(w;x)f(w)22,1nxDf(w;x)f(w)22, or also equivalently, Ex[f(w;x)2]f(w)2+2.Ex[f(w;x)2]f(w)2+2.

Let's derive the quadratic upper bound again (the "descent" lemma)

that is, for all x,yx,y,

f(y)f(x)+f(x),yx+L2yx2f(y)f(x)+f(x),yx+L2yx2

To begin, consider the univariate function and its derivative ()=f(x+(yx))()=f(x+(yx)),yx(1)(2)(1)()=f(x+(yx))(2)()=f(x+(yx)),yx

By the Fundamental Theorem of Calculus,

(1)(0)=10()d(1)(0)=01()d

If we substitute back in our definition of , we get f(y)f(x)=10f(x+(yx)),yx>df(y)=f(x)+f(x),yx+10f(x+(yx))f(x),yx>d(3)(4)(3)f(y)f(x)=01f(x+(yx)),yx>d(4)f(y)=f(x)+f(x),yx+01f(x+(yx))f(x),yx>d where in the last step we rearranged, followed by an add and subtract of f(x),yxf(x),yx.

We can now simplify this as follows. Keep in mind: we assume that for all x,yx,y, f(x)f(y)Lxyf(x)f(y)Lxy. f(y)=f(x)+f(x),yx+10f(x+(yx))f(x),yx>df(x)+f(x),yx+10f(x+(yx))f(x)yxdf(x)+f(x),yx+10Lx+(yx)xyxd=f(x)+f(x),yx+Lyx210d(5)(6)(7)(8)(5)f(y)=f(x)+f(x),yx+01f(x+(yx))f(x),yx>d(6)f(x)+f(x),yx+01f(x+(yx))f(x)yxd(7)f(x)+f(x),yx+01Lx+(yx)xyxd(8)=f(x)+f(x),yx+Lyx201d where the first inequality comes from Cauchy-Schwarz inequality abababab, and the second comes from our LL-Lipschitz continuous gradient assumption. which gives us the "descent" lemma (although, for SGD, we no longer guarantee descent) f(y)f(x)+f(x),yx+L2yx2.f(y)f(x)+f(x),yx+L2yx2.

Constant Step Size

Here, we have t=1/Lt=1/L

(K1t=0t2)E[f(w)2]f(w0)+2L2K1t=02tK2E[f(w)2]f(w0)+22LK2(18)(19)(18)(t=0K1t2)E[f(w)2]f(w0)+2L2t=0K1t2(19)K2E[f(w)2]f(w0)+22LK2

Multiplying both sides by 2K2K, E[f(w)2]2f(w0)K+2LE[f(w)2]2f(w0)K+2L

How should we interpret this?

E[f(w)2]2f(w0)K+2LE[f(w)2]2f(w0)K+2L

SGD with constant step size converges to a "noise ball" (a.k.a. "noise floor")! Gradient magnitude doesn't necessarily go to zero

Even if we run for a very large number of iterations, limK2f(w0)K+2L=2L0.limK2f(w0)K+2L=2L0. For many applications this is fine...but it seems somehow lacking.

How should we interpret this?

Question: how can we make the noise ball smaller?

We can make this arbitrarily small

E[f(w)2]2f(w0)K+2LE[f(w)2]2f(w0)K+2L

(Figure shamelessly stolen from Mark Schmidt)

We can make this arbitrarily small

By choosing the step size constant as a function of the number of steps KK we plan to run. If we minize the RHS of E[f(w)2]2f(w0)K+2LE[f(w)2]2f(w0)K+2L with respect to , we will get =min2f(w0)2LK,1L=min(2f(w0)2LK,1L) where the 1/L1/L came from the earlier requirement of L1L1 in order to get to this point (the progress bound).

Substitute this in, E[f(w)2]2f(w0)Kmax(2LK2f(w0),L)+2Lmin2f(w0)2LK,1LE[f(w)2]2f(w0)Kmax(2LK2f(w0),L)+2Lmin(2f(w0)2LK,1L)

Then since min(x,y)xmin(x,y)x and max(x,y)x+ymax(x,y)x+y, E[f(w)2]2f(w0)K(2LK2f(w0)+L)+2L2f(w0)2LK=2f(w0)2LK+2Lf(w0)K+2f(w0)2LK=8f(w0)2LK+2Lf(w0)K.E[f(w)2]2f(w0)K(2LK2f(w0)+L)+2L2f(w0)2LK=2f(w0)2LK+2Lf(w0)K+2f(w0)2LK=8f(w0)2LK+2Lf(w0)K. This is decreasing to zero as KK.
